title: 111_hr5093
content: The "Space to Schools Act of 2010" may be cited as the official title of this Act. The Act establishes a program. The "Space to Schools Act of 2010" authorizes the Secretary of Education to implement a program to encourage aerospace professionals to become teachers and promote STEM education in K-12 schools. Eligible individuals include former employees of NASA, its suppliers, or related contractors with relevant work experience. The "Space to Schools Act of 2010" allows aerospace professionals to become teachers in K-12 schools. Eligible individuals must have relevant work experience in the aerospace industry. Applications must be submitted to the Secretary of Education within 4 years of retirement or separation from aerospace employment. The "Space to Schools Act of 2010" allows aerospace professionals to transition into teaching roles in K-12 schools. Eligible individuals must have experience in the aerospace industry and meet specific selection criteria set by the Secretary of Education. This includes educational requirements for different teaching positions. To qualify for assistance as a vocational or technical teacher, applicants must have an associate degree, postsecondary training, or related certification, 6 or more years of work experience in the field, or meet state certification requirements. An applicant terminated for cause is ineligible for the Program. Eligible individuals must agree to become certified as a teacher and accept a full-time teaching position for at least 3 years. The Program requires eligible individuals to become certified as a school teacher for at least 3 years in subjects like science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. The Secretary may waive the commitment under certain circumstances. Participants may receive a stipend of up to $5,000 for obtaining teaching certification. The Program offers a stipend bonus of $10,000 to participants who agree to become highly qualified teachers and work full-time for at least 3 years in a high-need school, teaching in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics subjects. Participants may have to repay the stipend under certain circumstances. Participants may be required to repay the stipend if they fail to meet qualifications or obtain employment as a teacher, or if they voluntarily leave or are terminated from teaching during the 3-year service period. Participants who fail to meet qualifications or employment as a teacher may be required to reimburse the Secretary for a stipend or bonus received, with interest accruing from the notification of the amount due. The Secretary may require participants to reimburse the United States for any stipend or bonus received, with interest accruing. A discharge in bankruptcy will not release participants from this obligation. An Advisory Board will be established to collect feedback on best practices for recruitment in the Program. The Program aims to involve schools in licensing or certification training for teaching programs and coordinate with education needs at various levels. Reports on program activities are to be submitted annually to relevant committees. The Advisory Board provides information on the Program, including the number of participants, participating States, schools involved, grade levels taught, subjects taught, and hours of training completed for certification or licensing. It also defines terms such as "elementary school" and "highly qualified". The curr_chunk defines terms related to education such as "charter school", "eligible local educational agency", and "high-need school" as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The curr_chunk defines criteria for identifying students in poverty in schools, including eligibility for free lunches, assistance programs, and medical aid. It also clarifies the term "institution of higher education" as per the Higher Education Act of 1965. The curr_chunk defines the term "vocational school" and "Secretary" as per the Higher Education Act of 1965. Authorization of Appropriations: $20,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated for fiscal year 2011 and each of fiscal years 2012 through 2014 to carry out the Higher Education Act of 1965. Funds remain available until expended.
